awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:   Seeking Redress and Producing Justice in Diverse Forums
awd_abstract_narration:
When new legal systems subordinate customary law to universalizing constitutional authority during democratic transitions, justice seeking nevertheless persists outside the criminal justice system.  Those seeking redress for wrongdoing often pursue remedies in non-court forums, with victims appealing, for example, to chiefs, neighborhood groups, and family.  These non-court avenues for resolving disputes do not simply offer multiple routes to remedy; they also may offer alternative modes of constructing wrongdoing and producing justice.  This research project studies how remedies are sought and justice is produced in and between different forums of redress, examining the ways practices of justice shape indeterminate grievances into recognized categories of transgression.  The study asks three sets of questions:  1) How do victims of wrongdoing seek remedy? 2) What is the relationship between different forums of redress? 3) How is wrongdoing constituted as transgression through forums of redress?  This project promises to shed light on how people seek redress in various ways and contexts, and how interpersonal harm comes to be classified in different ways.  Claims to justice serve as the very foundation of citizenship. For example, Title IX complaints in American universities, military tribunals judging cases of officer misconduct, and vigilantism on behalf of family, friends, and neighbors offer different modes of arbitrating and adjudicating complaints outside criminal law and differing ideas about the relationship between citizens and states.  Thus the broader stakes of this project concern experiences of wrongdoing and political exclusion, especially among populations whose first recourse is not necessarily the criminal justice system.
 
To examine efforts to remedy wrongdoing, this project focuses on sexual violence and undertakes a case study of justice-seeking practices in the context of unwanted sex.  Sonia Rupcic, a PhD candidate in the Anthropology Department at the University of Michigan, will conduct a 12-month investigation in South Africa, employing a range of anthropological methods, including interviews with those involved in seeking and offering redress for wrongdoing, and observation in formal and informal forums of dispute resolution (e.g., courtrooms, chief tribunals, and neighborhood watch meetings). The research will follow the justice-seeking practices of victims and their families through diverse sites of redress and track the parallel movement of indeterminate grievances as they coalesce into distinct categories of wrongs.

por.por_cntn:
When new legal systems subordinate customary law to universalizing constitutional authority during democratic transitions, justice seeking nevertheless persists outside the criminal justice system. Those seeking redress for wrongdoing often pursue remedies in non-court forums, with victims appealing, for example, to chiefs, neighborhood groups, and family. These non-court avenues for resolving disputes do not simply offer multiple routes to remedy; they also may offer alternative modes of constructing wrongdoing and producing justice. This research project studied how remedies are sought and justice was produced in and between different forums of redress, examining the ways practices of justice shape indeterminate grievances into recognized categories of transgression. The study investigated three sets of questions: 1) How do victims of wrongdoing seek remedy? 2) What is the relationship between different forums of redress? 3) How is wrongdoing constituted as transgression through forums of redress?

This project was carried out across 12 months of ethnographic fieldwork in South Africa, employing a range of anthropological methods, including interviews with those involved in seeking and offering redress for wrongdoing, and observation in formal and informal forums of dispute resolution (e.g., courtrooms, chief tribunals, and neighborhood watch meetings). To examine efforts to remedy wrongdoing, this project undertook a case study approach of justice-seeking practices in the context of unwanted sex. Sonia Rupcic, a PhD candidate in the Anthropology Department at the University of Michigan, carried out this work.

Study findings contribute to three fields of scholarship. First, in the field of critical legal studies, the study empirically demonstrates that South African victims of sexual wrongdoing and their loved ones seek aid and recognition in a variety of publics. Activists and politicians often describe South Africa as the “rape capital of the world,” but “rape capital” as an imaginary of crisis obscures how unwanted sex, as an indeterminate transgression, is constituted through different material and discursive practices of redress. Through different forms of dispute resolution, sexual wrongdoing emerged as a transgression that was by turns logistical, biomedical, familial, ethnic or spiritual in nature. This work contributes to a small but growing legal scholarship informed by science and technology studies. Rather than taking transgression as prior to forums of redress, categories of wrongs emerge from practical activities of reparation and dispute specialty. Moreover, multiple regimes of culpability jostle together in ways that do not easily map onto a spatialized law/custom binary. This study thus opens new inquiries into the nature of “law” and “legal pluralism” in Africa.

Second, the study contributes to scholarship on gender-based violence. Scholars of Southern Africa highlight how projects of relational personhood are accomplished through affinal and reproductive relations. By foregrounding the role of gendered notions of personhood in thinking about normative sex, the study finds that it is not the decline of legal marriage that conditions intimate-partner violence, but the generalization of the “sexual contract” to relationships that have been neither ratified by civil recognition nor through exchange of bridewealth, but by unmarked material transfers. Thus, paying for meals, drinks, transport, clothing, or groceries sometimes conferred ambivalent and disputed conjugality. Among some men and women, everyday transfers gave license to unwanted sex, increasing women’s vulnerability in unpredictable ways. Women alluded to unwanted incursions by partners, not as violations of sexual autonomy, but as threats to bonds of dependence.

Third, the project offers new insights into postcolonial studies in thinking through race, ethnicity and violence. The study finds that therapeutic encounters between counselors and survivors can be thought of as moments of violent ethnogenesis, in which ethnically Vhavenda women are constructed as pliant and willing and further as flawed victims, citizens and moral subjects. In so doing, this study demonstrates the persistence of the homeland, as an enterprise of ethnic subjugation, in post-apartheid South Africa.
